questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 1 day. He has also had headaches, severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. He has hypertension, insomnia, and bipolar disorder. His medications include lisinopril, fluoxetine, atorvastatin, lithium, olanzapine, and alprazolam. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. He is somnolent and confused. His mucous membranes are dry. Neurological examination shows dysarthria, decreased muscle strength in all extremities, and a coarse tremor of the hands bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to intravenous fluid administration and electrolyte supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whole bowel irrigation (WBI) with polyethylene glycol solution can be effective in the acute setting when patients ingest large amounts of lithium. It is recommended for asymptomatic patients who are awake and present shortly (within 4 hours) after presumed ingestion. WBI is not recommended in symptomatic patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which may develop following therapy with a serotonergic drug such as fluoxetine. Serotonin syndrome can result in an altered mental status, tremor, tachypnea, and diarrhea. However, other clinical features such as hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia would also be present. The mucous membranes of the oral cavity are usually moist (due to sialorrhea) and the pupils would be dilated. Moreover, serotonin syndrome usually occurs within 24 hours of an increase in the dose and/or the addition of a serotonergic drug; there is no history of a recent change in the patient's medications.

C) CORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated for the treatment of lithium toxicity in patients with an altered mental status, seizures, and/or life-threatening arrhythmias. Other indications for hemodialysis include a serum lithium concentration > 5.0 mEq/L or > 4.0 mEq/L with evidence of renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL). Serum lithium concentration should be measured in all patients with suspected lithium toxicity at the time of presentation and it should be repeated at close intervals (initially every 2–4 hours) to monitor the therapeutic effects of fluid administration and hemodialysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam may be used to treat seizures that occur in patients with lithium intoxication. This patient does not have a history of seizures; a different therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene may be used to treat severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which may occur following therapy with lithium or olanzapine. NMS can result in an altered mental status and tachypnea. However, other clinical features, such as hyperthermia, rigidity, hypertension, tachycardia, and/or diaphoresis, would also be present.
questions.hint: This patient takes lithium and has likely become dehydrated (due to severe vomiting and diarrhea for the past 2 days), which predisposes him to acute lithium toxicity. Lithium toxicity manifests with neurological symptoms (altered mental status, dysarthria, decreased muscle strength, coarse tremor). In addition, patients with lithium toxicity commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), which can further exacerbate dehydration.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her father 20 minutes after he found her unconscious on her bedroom floor. The father reports that he had an argument with the patient earlier in the evening, after which she swallowed a handful of pills. She has major depressive disorder, anorexia nervosa, and migraine headaches. Her father has chronic constipation and hypothyroidism. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure 90/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry, flushed skin. Her pupils are dilated and react sluggishly to light. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and widened QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's widened QRS complexes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serotonergic overactivity (i.e., serotonin syndrome) can be caused by drugs such as TCAs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, triptans, and ergotamine. Serotonin syndrome manifests with tachycardia, hyperthermia, and altered mental status, as seen here. Given that this patient has major depressive disorder and migraine, she may have been prescribed one or more of the aforementioned drugs. However, this patient's wide QRS complex is not explained by serotonergic overactivity.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased potassium loss is seen in patients with anorexia nervosa, commonly as a result of laxative abuse. This patient with anorexia nervosa might have access to laxatives because her father has chronic constipation. However, the characteristic ECG findings in hypokalemia are U waves, T wave flattening, a prolonged PR interval, and/or a prolonged QT interval; a wide QRS complex is not explained by hypokalemia, although it can be seen in hyperkalemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Excessive beta-adrenergic receptor blockade due to a beta blocker overdose can cause hypotension and an altered mental status, as seen here. Additionally, this patient may have been prescribed beta blockers for migraine prophylaxis. However, typical ECG features of beta blocker toxicity are sinus bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); the wide QRS complex in this patient is not explained by beta-adrenergic receptor blockade.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs directly inhibit fast sodium channels and cause an intraventricular conduction delay, which manifests as wide QRS complexes. Wide QRS complexes correlate positively with the risk of seizures and ventricular tachyarrhythmias from TCA toxicity. A QRS complex > 100 ms in duration is, therefore, an indication for initiating sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) therapy in patients with TCA overdose. NaHCO3 therapy, which increases extracellular Na+ concentration, leads to an increased Na+ concentration gradient across the cellular membrane and thereby attenuates the Na+ channel blockade. In patients with CNS depression, avoidance of respiratory acidosis is important because acidemia increases the release of lipid- and protein-bound TCA as well as the binding of TCA to Na+ channels. NaHCO3 therapy as well as early intubation and mechanical ventilation is helpful in this regard.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus tachycardia (heart rate: ∼143/min)
– Left-axis deviation (R > S in lead I; S > R in aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼160 ms in lead II)
– QT prolongation (QTc ∼556 ms)
– Prominent R wave in aVR

In a patient with suspected drug overdose, wide complex sinus tachycardia with QT prolongation and a prominent R wave in aVR suggest sodium channel blocker toxicity, which may indicate TCA overdose.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenergic overactivity can be caused by an excessive intake of synthetic thyroid hormone. Adrenergic overactivity causes tachycardia, hyperthermia, and dilated pupils, as seen here. Additionally, this patient may have had access to thyroid medications because her father has hypothyroidism. However, her wide QRS complex is not explained by adrenergic overactivity; the classic ECG changes of increased adrenergic activity are sinus tachycardia with shortening of PR and QT intervals.
questions.hint: A combination of antimuscarinic effects (e.g., sedation, dry flushed skin, hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia) with α1 receptor blockade (hypotension) is suggestive of intoxication with tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), which are used in the treatment of major depressive disorder and for migraine prophylaxis. Another specific effect of TCAs is responsible for a wide QRS complex on ECG.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because TCAs have anticholinergic properties, administering anticholinergic atropine to this patient with suspected nortriptyline toxicity would worsen the symptoms caused by cholinergic blockade (urinary retention, tachycardia, bowel distention, dry skin). Instead, atropine is an antidote used in organophosphate poisoning, which results in parasympathetic hyperstimulation that manifests as sweating, vomiting, diarrhea, miosis, bradycardia, bronchospasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid overdose. Signs of opioid overdose include decreased respiratory rate, shallow breathing, bradycardia, and miosis, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote that is used for beta-blocker toxicity. Blockage of the beta receptors in the heart and blood vessels results in profound hypotension and bradycardia in patients with beta-blocker overdose. Glucagon enhances myocardial contractility via the cAMP pathway, which is independent of beta-receptor stimulation. Administration of glucagon is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA toxicity as it would worsen tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine has no role in the management of TCA toxicity but is an antidote for serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome manifests with autonomic hyperactivity (nausea, sweating, tremors, tachycardia, hypertension), neuromuscular hyperactivity (hyperreflexia, impaired gait), mental status changes (disorientation to place and time), and hyperthermia in patients taking serotonergic drugs (e.g., citalopram, venlafaxine). Dry skin and hypotension, as seen here, are not features of serotonin syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Ammonium chloride is used to acidify urine and facilitate urinary excretion of drugs that are weak bases (e.g., amphetamine). Although this patient presents with some signs of amphetamine toxicity, such as dilated pupils, tachycardia, and confusion, some key features such as agitation, delusions, and hypertension (not hypotension) are missing. TCA is also a weak base. However, TCA toxicity causes profound hypotension, resulting in tissue hypoperfusion and lactic acidosis (metabolic acidosis). Ammonium chloride should not be given to patients with TCA toxicity because it could worsen the metabolic acidosis.

F) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms) and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving arrhythmias, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) prevents the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active.

In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication.

G) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the treatment of choice for TCA-induced seizures. There is no role of prophylactic administration of lorazepam in patients with TCA toxicity who are not having a seizure.
questions.hint: This patient presents with prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms), tachycardia, hypotension, mydriasis, dry skin, and urinary retention. These symptoms are suggestive of an overdose of nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text: Ten days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-minute episode of myoclonic jerking movements and urinary incontinence. After regaining consciousness, the patient has no recollection of what happened and seems confused. He has bipolar disorder, which has been controlled with lithium maintenance therapy for the past 15 years, as well as hypertension, asthma, and chronic lower back pain. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry oral mucosa, muscle fasciculations, and bilateral coarse hand tremor. His speech is slow and he is disoriented. Which of the following is most likely to be the new medication that precipitated this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid overdose can cause altered mental status and myoclonic movements. However, it is unlikely to cause myoclonic seizures because it is an anticonvulsant. Additionally, valproic acid undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, valproic acid is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Advanced acetaminophen toxicity can lead to changes in mental status due to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause myoclonic movements that may be confused for a myoclonic seizure. There is no evidence, however, that this patient consumed high doses of acetaminophen, and he does not have other features of advanced acetaminophen toxicity, such as jaundice or bleeding diathesis. Acetaminophen undergoes hepatic clearance, does not interfere with renal excretion and reabsorption of lithium, and is not known to precipitate lithium toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Theophylline toxicity can cause neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures and tremors) and while it may exclusively manifest with neurologic symptoms, other features (e.g., tachycardia, arrhythmias) are also commonly seen. Additionally, theophylline is not routinely prescribed for asthma due to the risk of toxicity. Finally, since theophylline increases renal clearance and decreases serum concentrations of lithium, it is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity. This patient's symptoms are more likely to result from lithium toxicity following the prescription of more commonly used medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Concurrent use of fluoxetine and lithium increases the risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can result in myoclonus, altered mental status, and, in severe cases, seizures. However, serotonin syndrome typically develops within hours of initiating or increasing the dose of a precipitating drug and would be unlikely in this patient, who presents 10 days after starting a new medication. Additionally, fluoxetine undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, fluoxetine is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

E) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril, cause vasodilation of the efferent arterioles and a subsequent decrease in GFR, which can lead to renal impairment. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, and any cause of renal impairment (e.g., chronic kidney disease, NSAID use) or volume depletion (e.g., due to diuretic therapy, cardiovascular disease) can precipitate lithium toxicity. Older patients (> 65 years of age) are particularly at risk for lithium toxicity, given their overall lower decreased glomerular filtration rate. To ensure safety, frequent monitoring of lithium levels is recommended in all patients taking lithium, particularly when starting a new medication.
questions.hint: The introduction of a new medication alongside maintenance therapy with lithium has resulted in this patient developing lithium toxicity, which can cause myoclonic seizures, altered mental status, coarse tremors, and neuromuscular excitability.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 2 hours after the sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. She was found on the kitchen floor along with candies, prescription pills, and several bottles. Her father has a history of hypertension and chronic low back pain and her mother has fibromyalgia. On arrival, the patient is obtunded and appears dehydrated. Temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils, dry lips, and flushed skin. Bowel sounds are decreased. The patient is unable to cooperate with neurologic examinations. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen is begun. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote for beta-blocker poisoning, which can cause altered mental status and hypotension, both of which are seen here. Additionally, this patient might have had access to beta-blockers because her father has hypertension. However, characteristic ECG features of beta-blocker toxicity are bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); tachycardia and wide QRS complex would not be expected. Moreover, other features seen in this patient, e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects), cannot be explained by beta-blocker poisoning. Glucagon administration is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA intoxication, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine can be used as an antidote in severe anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). While this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., dry skin), the additional features suggest TCA intoxication. Physostigmine is contraindicated in patients with TCA intoxication because it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, which can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of acute liver failure, altered mental status. In addition, this patient may have had access to acetaminophen. However, hepatic toxicity typically becomes symptomatic within 24 hours of acetaminophen ingestion and manifests with additional symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. Moreover, the anticholinergic features seen in this patient (e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, flushed skin, arrhythmia) cannot be explained by acetaminophen poisoning. NAC is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving ventricular arrhythmias or QRS complexes > 100 ms, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) can prevent the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active. In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication. In patients presenting within 2 hours of TCA ingestion, gastric decontamination with activated charcoal can be performed if the airway is established and circulation is secured.

Antiarrhythmics that are typically used in the management of ventricular tachycardia (e.g., procainamide, amiodarone) are contraindicated in TCA overdose because of the risk of worsening sodium channel blockade and/or QTc prolongation.

E) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid intoxication. Although this patient has some features of opioid intoxication (respiratory depression, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status, hypotension) and may have had access to opioids (father has a history of chronic low back pain), she presents with mydriasis instead of miosis, which would be the expected finding in opioid intoxication. Moreover, hyperthermia and wide QRS complexes on ECG cannot be explained by opioid toxicity. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication. TCAs are used in the treatment of fibromyalgia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-hour history of nausea, dizziness, and confusion. Five hours ago, he told his wife he ingested a handful of pills “to put an end to it all.” He has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, low back pain, and major depressive disorder. His medications are ramipril, metoprolol, acetaminophen, and nortriptyline. On arrival, he is awake but confused. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry, flushed skin. The abdomen is distended, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. In addition to maintaining a patent airway and administering intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen (APAP) overdose and does not play a role in TCA overdose.

Because APAP overdose may initially be asymptomatic or manifest with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., nausea), this patient should also be managed for potential APAP coingestion. However, in suspected acute, nonmassive APAP overdose, serum APAP level should be measured before NAC administration.

B) INCORRECT:

Sodium bicarbonate is used to counter the effects of cardiotoxic drugs with sodium channel blocking properties, such as TCAs. However, due to the risk of adverse effects (e.g., electrolyte imbalances, alkalemia), sodium bicarbonate is only indicated in patients with TCA toxicity with QRS interval > 100 ms or ventricular arrhythmias. This patient should first be evaluated for cardiotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine immunoassay is a qualitative test that can be used for screening if the medications of a patient with suspected overdose are unknown. Performing a urine immunoassay is not useful in this patient whose symptoms are most likely due to TCA toxicity. This test would delay another, more important step in management and would not provide additional prognostic or therapeutic information.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is used as an antidote in the treatment of beta-blocker toxicity, which can manifest with neurological symptoms (e.g., dizziness, confusion) similar to what is seen in this patient whose medications include metoprolol. However, beta blockers characteristically cause bradycardia, whereas this patient is tachycardic. In addition, features such as hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects) are not associated with beta-blocker toxicity. This patient most likely has a TCA overdose, for which glucagon is not recommended, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

E) CORRECT:

In known or suspected TCA toxicity, an immediate ECG is necessary to evaluate for conduction abnormalities (e.g., prolonged QRS, QT prolongation). Inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels due to an overdose of TCAs can result in cardiotoxicity. The width of the QRS complexes, which corresponds to the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures, indicates the severity of intoxication. Sodium bicarbonate is used to counter the cardiotoxic effects of TCAs and is indicated in patients with QRS ≥ 100 ms or ventricular arrhythmias. If an airway is established, activated charcoal can be administered within 2 hours of ingestion to prevent further absorption of TCAs. When TCA overdose is suspected but medications are unknown, a urine immunoassay can help establish the diagnosis. This test should not delay further management (e.g., airway establishment, fluid resuscitation, ECG).

To rule out hypoglycemia, measuring capillary blood glucose levels is indicated in all patients with altered mental status. In addition, serum acetaminophen levels should be taken to rule out co-ingestion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., altered mental status, hyperthermia, tachycardia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin) and alpha-1 adrenergic receptor inhibition (hypotension), which together raise suspicion for an overdose of nortryptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man who is being treated for depression is brought to the emergency department in a confused state by his mother, who found him with several empty, unlabeled pill bottles. He has been depressed since his fiancée left him 3 weeks ago. His mother does not know what medications he has been taking.
An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia, a QRS complex width of 160 msec, and a corrected QT interval of 550 msec. A comparison electrocardiogram obtained one month ago was normal.
Which intravenous therapy is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is a beta-blocker with no appropriate role in the management of this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor with no appropriate role in the management of this patient, given that it increases the risk for cardiac arrest in the setting of TCA overdose.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of certain antiarrhythmic drugs in the setting of TCA overdose can lead to worsening ventricular arrhythmias. Class Ia antiarrhythmic drugs such as procainamide may further widen the QRS complex in such cases. There is early evidence that class Ib antiarrhythmics such as lidocaine may provide some benefit in TCA poisoning, but the recommendation from the American Heart Association (AHA) is weak (Class 2b).

D) CORRECT:

This patient with a history of depression and acutely altered mental status has new-onset widened QRS and QT intervals. These findings may be due to ingestion of a toxic dose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). The patient’s serum TCA concentration should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. However, given that the results of such testing may not be available for many hours, treatment of a suspected TCA overdose should be initiated immediately.

Intravenous sodium bicarbonate — which alkalinizes the serum and increases TCA protein binding, thereby decreasing the amount of cardioactive drug — is the treatment of choice for suspected TCA overdose that results in QRS prolongation.

In addition to sedation and conduction abnormalities, patients with TCA intoxication can present with tachycardia, hypotension, seizures, and manifestations of anticholinergic toxicity (dilated pupils, dry mouth, decreased bowel sounds, urinary retention, and hyperthermia).

Key learning point: The best treatment for a suspected tricyclic antidepressant overdose that is complicated by a widened QRS complex and QT prolongation is intravenous sodium bicarbonate.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus tachycardia (heart rate: ∼143/min)
– Left-axis deviation (R > S in lead I; S > R in aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼160 ms in lead II)
– QT prolongation (QTc ∼556 ms)
– Prominent R wave in aVR

In a patient with suspected drug overdose, wide complex sinus tachycardia with QT prolongation and a prominent R wave in aVR suggest sodium channel blocker toxicity, which may indicate TCA overdose.

E) INCORRECT:

Use of certain antiarrhythmic drugs in the setting of TCA overdose can lead to worsening ventricular arrhythmias. Class III antiarrhythmics such as amiodarone may further prolong the QT interval. There is early evidence that class Ib antiarrhythmics such as lidocaine may provide some benefit in TCA poisoning, but the recommendation from the American Heart Association (AHA) is weak (Class 2b).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of constipation, fatigue, muscle weakness, polyuria, and polydipsia. She has hypertension, which is treated with amlodipine 5 mg daily, and bipolar disorder, which has been treated with lithium 300 mg three times daily for the past 2 years.
On examination, her blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg, her heart rate is 78 beats per minute, and her BMI is 32.
Her serum calcium level is 11.5 mg/dL, compared with 9.8 mg/dL three years ago (reference range, 9.0–10.5). Other current laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Albumin (g/dL)
3.9
3.5–5.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
2.5
3.0–4.5


Parathyroid hormone (pg/mL)
85
10–60


25-hydroxyvitamin D (ng/mL)
31
30–80


Magnesium (mg/dL)
1.9
1.8–3.0


A complete blood count and results of electrolyte, kidney, and liver function tests are normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder
Order nuclear imaging of the parathyroid glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis would be the next step if multiple myeloma were the suspected cause of the patient’s hypercalcemia. However, myeloma usually manifests in older patients and with other findings such as anemia, kidney dysfunction, and bone pain. Moreover, the parathyroid hormone level would be low in myeloma.

B) CORRECT:

The workup of hypercalcemia begins with measuring the parathyroid hormone level. If it is elevated in a patient with normal kidney function, then primary hyperparathyroidism should be considered. However, lithium can increase the set point at which the serum calcium level suppresses parathyroid hormone secretion; this results in an elevated parathyroid hormone level and hypercalcemia. In this patient, the lithium should be stopped if possible; if the serum calcium level does not normalize, further evaluation for primary hyperparathyroidism (which could include parathyroid imaging or referral to a parathyroid surgeon) should be considered.

Key learning point: Lithium can affect secretion of parathyroid hormone by causing primary hyperparathyroidism and subsequent hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate, are appropriate for treating symptomatic hypercalcemia, such as occurs with hypercalcemia of malignancy, but they are not indicated in a patient who has features of a secondary, reversible cause of hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, which can also result in an elevated parathyroid hormone level, is an autosomal-dominant mutation in the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands and kidney that leads to an increase in the serum calcium level necessary to suppress parathyroid hormone secretion by the parathyroid. Screening for this condition consists of measuring 24-hour urinary calcium excretion. However, the patient’s past normal serum calcium levels make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

The workup of hypercalcemia begins with measuring the parathyroid hormone level. If it is elevated in a patient with normal kidney function, then primary hyperparathyroidism should be considered. However, lithium can increase the set point at which the serum calcium level suppresses parathyroid hormone secretion; this results in an elevated parathyroid hormone level and hypercalcemia. In this patient, the lithium should be stopped if possible; if the serum calcium level does not normalize, further evaluation for primary hyperparathyroidism (which could include parathyroid imaging or referral to a parathyroid surgeon) should be considered.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder treated with stable doses of lithium and risperidone for 12 years is brought to the emergency department. Three days ago, he had fever, myalgias, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These symptoms have gradually improved, but during the past 24 hours, he has developed confusion and agitation.
On examination, his blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 106 beats per minute. His speech is slurred; he appears agitated and confused and is oriented to self only. His oral mucous membranes are dry, and his skin turgor is reduced. His gait is ataxic, and a tremor is noted in the extremities.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
152
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.6
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
119
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
20
21–30


Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.4
0.8–1.3


Urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
52
10–20


Two months ago, routine laboratory testing showed a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 14 mg/dL.
His urinalysis today shows trace protein and a specific gravity of 1.010 (reference range, 1.001–1.035).
Which one of the following diagnoses most likely explains this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxicity from atypical antipsychotic drugs (e.g., risperidone) can cause various central nervous system symptoms, and acute mania can present with cognitive abnormalities, irritability, and psychosis. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and laboratory findings are more consistent with lithium toxicity than with either of those diagnoses.

B) INCORRECT:

Lithium therapy is associated with nephrogenic, not central, diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Several drugs may lead to chronic interstitial nephritis, but this diagnosis is not consistent with the patient’s acute presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxicity from atypical antipsychotic drugs (e.g., risperidone) can cause various central nervous system symptoms, and acute mania can present with cognitive abnormalities, irritability, and psychosis. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and laboratory findings are more consistent with lithium toxicity than with either of those diagnoses.

E) CORRECT:

Because lithium is excreted by the kidneys, patients receiving this medication can develop toxicity in the setting of volume depletion or with the addition of medications that reduce clearance of lithium (e.g., nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors).

In this case, the patient had a recent gastroenteritis that likely led to volume depletion. In addition, this patient may have underlying nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, a common complication of chronic lithium use, which would make him more susceptible to hypernatremia when he is unable to drink enough fluids to match urinary losses. When patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus develop volume depletion, they cannot respond to vasopressin. Therefore, the expected maximal concentration of urine does not occur. Instead, the urine may remain dilute — or if renal injury is severe, the urine volume will be very limited and the osmolality will be similar to that of plasma because kidney failure limits the ability to either dilute or concentrate the urine.

Lithium toxicity can cause tremor, cognitive impairment, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Lithium levels above 1.5 mEq/L are typically associated with symptoms, and levels above 2.5 mEq/L are considered a medical emergency.

Key learning point: In a patient receiving long-term lithium therapy, a common precipitant of toxicity is volume depletion, resulting in reduced clearance of lithium.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with a history of depression is brought in by emergency medical services (EMS) after she texted her mother that she had had an argument with her boyfriend and ingested a handful of prescription pills. EMS found the girl agitated and combative. The mother does not remember the name of her daughter’s medication.
On arrival, the patient has a temperature of 38.3°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, a blood pressure of 85/40 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 95% while breathing ambient air. She is agitated and confused, and she reports blurry vision. Both pupils are 8 mm and minimally reactive, her lungs are clear to auscultation, her abdomen appears distended with hypoactive bowel sounds, and her skin is warm and dry. She has normal tone and reflexes without clonus.
An electrocardiogram identifies sinus tachycardia with a QRS duration of 120 msec and a corrected QT (QTc) interval of 460 msec.
Venous blood gas and fingerstick testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


pH
7.33
7.35–7.45


Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (mm Hg)
44
32–48


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
22
20–28


Base excess (mEq/liter)
–3
–2 to +2


Glucose (mg/dL)
110
60–100


A peripheral intravenous line is placed, and a bolus of normal saline is administered.
After initial stabilization, which one of the following treatments is most important to administer to this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be considered for use within one hour of substance ingestion and has been shown to reduce TCA absorption and bioavailability. However, charcoal carries a potential risk of aspiration and should be used only in patients with a protected airway. This patient is agitated and at risk for seizures or respiratory depression. These factors increase her risk for aspiration and make her a poor candidate for charcoal.

B) INCORRECT:

Although there is no evidence that lipid emulsion is beneficial as a standard treatment for TCA overdose, it may be considered to treat life-threatening toxicity that is refractory to first-line treatments such as sodium bicarbonate.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine should be used within 8 hours of acetaminophen ingestion to prevent hepatotoxicity. The patient could certainly have a coingestion and should undergo comprehensive toxicology testing. However, at this point, the patient is presenting with a toxidrome consistent with TCA ingestion and an ECG identifying a prolonged QTc interval. This patient is thus at risk for life-threatening arrhythmias and should be treated with sodium bicarbonate first.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a toxidrome consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity. Treatment is indicated because her electrocardiogram (ECG) findings are associated with an increased risk for dysrhythmias and seizures.

This patient demonstrates several elements of the anticholinergic syndrome, including tachycardia, hyperthermia, blurred vision, mydriasis, dry skin, impaired intestinal motility, and ECG changes. Her dry skin and the minimal reactivity of her pupils help to distinguish her condition from a sympathomimetic toxidrome; in the latter syndrome, the patient would retain pupil reactivity, and her skin would be diaphoretic. In addition, her normal reflexes and lack of clonus help to distinguish her condition from serotonin syndrome.

TCAs block alpha-adrenergic and muscarinic receptors, causing hypotension and an anticholinergic syndrome, respectively. They also block sodium channels in the myocardium, prolonging the QRS and corrected QT (QTc) intervals. The presence of QRS prolongation (>100 msec) and QTc prolongation (>430 msec) is associated with an increased risk for seizures and ventricular dysrhythmias; with a QRS duration of 120 msec and a QTc interval of 460 msec, this patient is at high risk for these complications. Hypotension, as seen in this patient, is due to a combination of myocardial depression and reduced systemic vascular resistance secondary to the anti-alpha-adrenergic effects of TCA overdose. A fluid bolus will not reverse either of these effects but can help to optimize cardiac preload.

Sodium bicarbonate is the first-line treatment in TCA overdose because it alkalinizes the blood pH and increases plasma protein binding of TCAs, thereby reducing the pharmacologically active unbound compound. Other reported benefits include augmentation of myocardial contractility, which can elevate blood pressure and resolve hypotension, and improvement in intraventricular conduction, which shortens the QRS segment. The Guidelines in Emergency Medicine Network (GEMNet) recommend administering sodium bicarbonate in TCA overdose, with a goal pH of 7.50 to 7.55, even in the absence of initial acidosis. This goal can be achieved by starting with 1- to 2-mEq/kg boluses and then titrating the infusion until a QRS duration of 100 msec or lower is achieved.

Key learning point: The best predictor of complications after a tricyclic antidepressant overdose is an electrocardiogram that identifies a QRS duration >100 msec or a QTc interval >430 msec.

E) INCORRECT:

Fomepizole is important in managing poisoning by ethylene glycol and methanol (most commonly found in antifreeze, fuels, and solvents). Toxic alcohol poisoning typically manifests with symptoms that mimic ethanol intoxication. Ethylene glycol may cause nephrotoxicity, and methanol poisoning can cause retinal toxicity. These toxins would be unlikely to cause the hyperthermia, hypotension, or anticholinergic symptoms seen in this case of TCA poisoning.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department in a confused state by his mother, who says he confessed to her that he “took a lot of Grandma’s pills” before arrival. He has been depressed since his girlfriend broke up with him 2 months ago, and he shares a bathroom with his grandmother, who takes multiple medications for back pain, depression, and heartburn.
An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia, a QRS complex width of 160 msec, and a corrected QT interval of 550 msec. A comparison electrocardiogram obtained one month ago was normal.
In addition to naloxone, which intravenous therapy is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient, who has a recent history of depression, presented with acutely altered mental status, and his ECG demonstrates new-onset widened QRS and QT intervals. These findings together most likely suggest ingestion of a toxic dose of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs).

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the patient’s serum TCA concentration. However, the results of such testing may not be available for many hours, and treatment of a suspected TCA overdose should be initiated immediately. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate — which alkalinizes the serum and increases TCA protein binding, thereby decreasing the amount of cardioactive drug — is the treatment of choice for a suspected TCA overdose that results in QRS prolongation. Treating this patient with naloxone would also be appropriate, given that intoxication with certain opioids can cause QT prolongation and this patient had access to his grandmother’s pain medications.

Use of certain antiarrhythmic drugs in the setting of TCA overdose can lead to worsening ventricular arrhythmias. There is early evidence that class Ib antiarrhythmics such as lidocaine may provide some benefit in TCA poisoning, but the recommendation from the American Heart Association is weak (Class 2b).

In addition to sedation and conduction abnormalities, patients with TCA intoxication can present with tachycardia, hypotension, seizures, and manifestations of anticholinergic toxicity (dilated pupils, dry mouth, decreased bowel sounds, urinary retention, and hyperthermia).

Key learning point: The best treatment for a suspected tricyclic antidepressant overdose that is complicated by a widened QRS complex and QT prolongation is intravenous sodium bicarbonate.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus tachycardia (heart rate: ∼143/min)
– Left-axis deviation (R > S in lead I; S > R in aVF)
– Widened QRS complexes (∼160 ms in lead II)
– QT prolongation (QTc ∼556 ms)
– Prominent R wave in aVR

In a patient with suspected drug overdose, wide complex sinus tachycardia with QT prolongation and a prominent R wave in aVR suggest sodium channel blocker toxicity, which may indicate TCA overdose.

B) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is a beta-blocker with no appropriate role in the management of this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of certain antiarrhythmic drugs in the setting of TCA overdose can lead to worsening ventricular arrhythmias. Class Ia antiarrhythmic drugs such as procainamide may further widen the QRS complex.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of certain antiarrhythmic drugs in the setting of TCA overdose can lead to worsening ventricular arrhythmias. Class III antiarrhythmics such as amiodarone may further prolong the QT interval.

E) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor with no appropriate role in the management of this patient, given that it increases the risk for cardiac arrest in the setting of TCA overdose.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because TCAs have anticholinergic properties, administering anticholinergic atropine to this patient with suspected nortriptyline toxicity would worsen the symptoms caused by cholinergic blockade (urinary retention, tachycardia, bowel distention, dry skin). Instead, atropine is an antidote used in organophosphate poisoning, which results in parasympathetic hyperstimulation that manifests as sweating, vomiting, diarrhea, miosis, bradycardia, bronchospasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid overdose. Signs of opioid overdose include decreased respiratory rate, shallow breathing, bradycardia, and miosis, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine has no role in the management of TCA toxicity but is an antidote for serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome manifests with autonomic hyperactivity (nausea, sweating, tremors, tachycardia, hypertension), neuromuscular hyperactivity (hyperreflexia, impaired gait), mental status changes (disorientation to place and time), and hyperthermia in patients taking serotonergic drugs (e.g., citalopram, venlafaxine). Dry skin and hypotension, as seen here, are not features of serotonin syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms) and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving arrhythmias, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) prevents the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active.

In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication.

E) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the treatment of choice for TCA-induced seizures. There is no role of prophylactic administration of lorazepam in patients with TCA toxicity who are not having a seizure.
questions.hint: This patient presents with prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms), tachycardia, hypotension, mydriasis, dry skin, and urinary retention. These symptoms are suggestive of an overdose of nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 1 day. He has also had headaches, severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. He has hypertension and bipolar disorder. His medications include lisinopril, fluoxetine, atorvastatin, lithium, and olanzapine. He is somnolent and confused. His mucous membranes are dry. Neurological examination shows dysarthria, decreased muscle strength in all extremities, and a coarse tremor of the hands bilaterally. In addition to intravenous fluid administration and electrolyte supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal can be effective in the acute setting when patients ingest large amounts of certain toxic substances. However, activated charcoal does not bind to lithium; a different therapy is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which may develop following therapy with a serotonergic drug such as fluoxetine. Serotonin syndrome can result in an altered mental status, tremor, tachypnea, and diarrhea. However, other clinical features such as hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia would also be present. The mucous membranes of the oral cavity are usually moist (due to sialorrhea) and the pupils would be dilated. Moreover, serotonin syndrome usually occurs within 24 hours of an increase in the dose and/or the addition of a serotonergic drug; there is no history of a recent change in the patient's medications.

C) CORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated for the treatment of lithium toxicity in patients with an altered mental status, seizures, and/or life-threatening arrhythmias. Other indications for hemodialysis include a serum lithium concentration > 5.0 mEq/L or > 4.0 mEq/L with evidence of renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL). Serum lithium concentration should be measured in all patients with suspected lithium toxicity at the time of presentation and it should be repeated at close intervals (initially every 2–4 hours) to monitor the therapeutic effects of fluid administration and hemodialysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam may be used to treat seizures that occur in patients with lithium intoxication. This patient does not have a history of seizures; a different therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene may be used to treat severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which may occur following therapy with lithium or olanzapine. NMS can result in an altered mental status and tachypnea. However, other clinical features, such as hyperthermia, rigidity, hypertension, tachycardia, and/or diaphoresis, would also be present.
questions.hint: This patient takes lithium and has likely become dehydrated (due to severe vomiting and diarrhea for the past 2 days), which predisposes him to acute lithium toxicity. Lithium toxicity manifests with neurological symptoms (altered mental status, dysarthria, decreased muscle strength, coarse tremor). In addition, patients with lithium toxicity commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), which can further exacerbate dehydration.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of constipation, fatigue, muscle weakness, polyuria, and polydipsia. She has bipolar disorder, which has been treated with lithium for the past 2 years. Her pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg, and BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her serum calcium level is 11.5 mg/dL, compared with 9.8 mg/dL three years ago (N = 9.0–10.5). Other laboratory findings are as follows:


Serum



Albumin
3.9 g/dL


Phosphate
2.5 mg/dL



Parathyroid hormone

85 pg/mL


25-hydroxyvitamin D
31 ng/mL (N = 30–80)


Magnesium (mg/dL)
1.9 mg/dL


A complete blood count and results of electrolyte, kidney, and liver function tests are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder
Order nuclear imaging of the parathyroid glands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis would be the next step if multiple myeloma were the suspected cause of the patient’s hypercalcemia. However, myeloma usually manifests in older patients and with other findings such as anemia, kidney dysfunction, and bone pain. Moreover, the parathyroid hormone level would be low in myeloma.

B) CORRECT:

The workup of hypercalcemia begins with measuring the parathyroid hormone level. If it is elevated in a patient with normal kidney function, then primary hyperparathyroidism should be considered. However, lithium can increase the set point at which the serum calcium level suppresses parathyroid hormone secretion; this results in an elevated parathyroid hormone level and hypercalcemia. In this patient, the lithium should be stopped if possible; if the serum calcium level does not normalize, further evaluation for primary hyperparathyroidism (which could include parathyroid imaging or referral to a parathyroid surgeon) should be considered.

Key learning point: Lithium can affect secretion of parathyroid hormone by causing primary hyperparathyroidism and subsequent hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate, are appropriate for treating symptomatic hypercalcemia, such as occurs with hypercalcemia of malignancy, but they are not indicated in a patient who has features of a secondary, reversible cause of hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, which can also result in an elevated parathyroid hormone level, is an autosomal-dominant mutation in the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands and kidney that leads to an increase in the serum calcium level necessary to suppress parathyroid hormone secretion by the parathyroid. Screening for this condition consists of measuring 24-hour urinary calcium excretion. However, the patient’s past normal serum calcium levels make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid imaging is considered in further evaluation of a patient for primary hyperparathyroidism. However, parathyroid imaging is not indicated in a patient who has features of a secondary, reversible cause of hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. She was found with an open bottle of her mother's antidepressive medication. On arrival, the patient is obtunded. Temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils, dry lips, flushed skin, and decreased bowel sounds. Electrocardiography shows sinus tachycardia and a widened QRS complex (130 ms). Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen is begun. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote for beta-blocker poisoning, which can cause altered mental status and hypotension, both of which are seen here. Characteristic ECG features of beta-blocker toxicity are bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); tachycardia and wide QRS complex would not be expected. Other features seen in this patient, e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects), cannot be explained by beta-blocker poisoning. Glucagon administration is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA intoxication, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine can be used as an antidote in severe anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). While this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., dry skin), additional findings suggest TCA intoxication. Physostigmine is contraindicated in patients with TCA intoxication because it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, which can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of acute liver failure, altered mental status. In acetaminophen poisoning, hepatic toxicity typically becomes symptomatic within 24 hours of ingestion and manifests with additional symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. The anticholinergic features seen in this patient (e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, flushed skin, arrhythmia) cannot be explained by acetaminophen poisoning. NAC is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving ventricular arrhythmias or QRS complexes > 100 ms, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) can prevent the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active. In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication. In patients presenting within 2 hours of TCA ingestion, gastric decontamination with activated charcoal can be performed if the airway is established and circulation is secured.

Antiarrhythmics that are typically used in the management of ventricular tachycardia (e.g., procainamide, amiodarone) are contraindicated in TCA overdose because of the risk of worsening sodium channel blockade and/or QTc prolongation.

E) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid intoxication. Although this patient has some features of opioid intoxication (respiratory depression, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status, hypotension), she has ingested TCAs, not opioids. Additionally, the patient presents with mydriasis instead of miosis, which would be the expected finding in opioid intoxication. Hyperthermia and wide QRS complexes on ECG cannot be explained by opioid toxicity. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with depression is brought in unresponsive after ingesting a large quantity of citalopram. Which complication is most likely to occur from this overdose?

choices.text: QT prolongation leading to torsades de pointes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Citalopram overdose is associated with cardiotoxicity due to its blockade of hERG potassium channels, which are crucial for cardiac repolarization. This blockade results in QT interval prolongation on the electrocardiogram, increasing the risk of torsades de pointes, a potentially fatal polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Early recognition and management of QT prolongation are essential to prevent life-threatening arrhythmias.

Key learning point: Citalopram is the most toxic SSRI in overdose due to its potential to cause QT interval prolongation and serious cardiac arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe hypotension is linked to drugs with significant alpha-adrenergic blockade, such as tricyclic antidepressants. Citalopram, an SSRI, does not significantly affect alpha receptors. Its overdose effects include cardiac conduction disturbances and seizures, not severe hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia from selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like citalopram occurs via syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) with chronic use, not acute overdose. Acute overdose primarily causes cardiac and central nervous system effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Serotonin syndrome involves neuromuscular hyperactivity, autonomic instability, and altered mental status, often with agitation. Citalopram overdose typically presents with unresponsiveness, seizures, or cardiac conduction abnormalities, not the hyperactivity seen in serotonin syndrome, which is more common with multiple serotonergic agents.

questions.text: Ten days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a 3-minute episode of myoclonic jerking movements and urinary incontinence. After regaining consciousness, he is amnestic to the event and appears confused. He has a history of bipolar disorder managed with lithium maintenance therapy for the past 15 years, as well as hypertension, asthma, and chronic lower back pain. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. On examination, he has dry oral mucosa, muscle fasciculations, and a coarse bilateral hand tremor. His speech is slow and he is disoriented. Which one of the following is most likely to be the new medication that precipitated his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Advanced acetaminophen toxicity can lead to changes in mental status due to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause myoclonic movements that may be confused for a myoclonic seizure. There is no evidence, however, that this patient consumed high doses of acetaminophen, and he does not have other features of advanced acetaminophen toxicity, such as jaundice or bleeding diathesis. Acetaminophen undergoes hepatic clearance, does not interfere with renal excretion and reabsorption of lithium, and is not known to precipitate lithium toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid overdose can cause altered mental status and myoclonic movements. However, it is unlikely to cause myoclonic seizures because it is an anticonvulsant. Additionally, valproic acid undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, valproic acid is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

C) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril, cause vasodilation of the efferent arterioles and a subsequent decrease in GFR, which can lead to renal impairment. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, and any cause of renal impairment (e.g., chronic kidney disease, NSAID use) or volume depletion (e.g., due to diuretic therapy, cardiovascular disease) can precipitate lithium toxicity. Older patients (> 65 years of age) are particularly at risk for lithium toxicity, given their overall lower decreased glomerular filtration rate. To ensure safety, frequent monitoring of lithium levels is recommended in all patients taking lithium, particularly when starting a new medication.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors can precipitate lithium toxicity by reducing renal clearance of lithium, especially in older adults or those with impaired kidney function.

D) INCORRECT:

Concurrent use of fluoxetine and lithium increases the risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can result in myoclonus, altered mental status, and, in severe cases, seizures. However, serotonin syndrome typically develops within hours of initiating or increasing the dose of a precipitating drug and would be unlikely in this patient, who presents 10 days after starting a new medication. Additionally, fluoxetine undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, fluoxetine is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Theophylline toxicity can cause neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures and tremors) and while it may exclusively manifest with neurologic symptoms, other features (e.g., tachycardia, arrhythmias) are also commonly seen. Additionally, theophylline is not routinely prescribed for asthma due to the risk of toxicity. Finally, since theophylline increases renal clearance and decreases serum concentrations of lithium, it is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity. This patient's symptoms are more likely to result from lithium toxicity following the prescription of more commonly used medication.
questions.hint: The introduction of a new medication alongside maintenance therapy with lithium has resulted in this patient developing lithium toxicity, which can cause myoclonic seizures, altered mental status, coarse tremors, and neuromuscular excitability.

questions.text: You are seeing a 41-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him unresponsive on the bathroom floor with an empty medication bottle nearby. He has a history of major depressive disorder and his only medication is nortriptyline. On assessment, his pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mm Hg. He has dilated pupils, dry skin, a distended abdomen, and suprapubic dullness to percussion. ECG shows tachycardia with a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid overdose. Signs of opioid overdose include decreased respiratory rate, shallow breathing, bradycardia, and miosis, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Because TCAs have anticholinergic properties, administering anticholinergic atropine to this patient with suspected nortriptyline toxicity would worsen the symptoms caused by cholinergic blockade (urinary retention, tachycardia, bowel distention, dry skin). Instead, atropine is an antidote used in organophosphate poisoning, which results in parasympathetic hyperstimulation that manifests as sweating, vomiting, diarrhea, miosis, bradycardia, bronchospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, is the treatment of choice for TCA-induced seizures. There is no role of prophylactic administration of lorazepam in patients with TCA toxicity who are not having a seizure.

D) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms) and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving arrhythmias, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) prevents the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active.

In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication.

Key learning point: Sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice for tricyclic antidepressant overdose with cardiac toxicity, as it stabilizes cardiac membranes and narrows QRS complexes.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine has no role in the management of TCA toxicity but is an antidote for serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome manifests with autonomic hyperactivity (nausea, sweating, tremors, tachycardia, hypertension), neuromuscular hyperactivity (hyperreflexia, impaired gait), mental status changes (disorientation to place and time), and hyperthermia in patients taking serotonergic drugs (e.g., citalopram, venlafaxine). Dry skin and hypotension, as seen here, are not features of serotonin syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient presents with prolonged QRS complexes (≥ 100 ms), tachycardia, hypotension, mydriasis, dry skin, and urinary retention. These symptoms are suggestive of an overdose of nortriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of constipation, fatigue, muscle weakness, polyuria, and polydipsia. She has a history of bipolar disorder and has been taking lithium for the past 2 years. Her pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg, and BMI is 32. Her serum total calcium is 2.88 mmol/L (2.12–2.52), compared with 2.45 mmol/L three years ago. Additional laboratory findings are as follows:


Albumin, blood
39 g/L (34–50)


Phosphate (PO4), blood
0.81 mmol/L (0.81–1.58)


Parathyroid hormone (PTH), blood

9.0 pmol/L (1.6–9.3)


Vitamin D (25-hydroxyvitamin D), blood
77.5 nmol/L (75–250)


Magnesium (Mg), blood
0.78 mmol/L (0.74–1.03)


Complete blood count and electrolyte, kidney, and liver function tests are normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in her care?

choices.text: Replace lithium with an alternative treatment for bipolar disorder.
Order nuclear imaging of the parathyroid glands.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate, are appropriate for treating symptomatic hypercalcemia, such as occurs with hypercalcemia of malignancy, but they are not indicated in a patient who has features of a secondary, reversible cause of hypercalcemia.

B) CORRECT:

The workup of hypercalcemia begins with measuring the parathyroid hormone level. If it is elevated in a patient with normal kidney function, then primary hyperparathyroidism should be considered. However, lithium can increase the set point at which the serum calcium level suppresses parathyroid hormone secretion; this results in an elevated parathyroid hormone level and hypercalcemia. In this patient, the lithium should be stopped if possible; if the serum calcium level does not normalize, further evaluation for primary hyperparathyroidism (which could include parathyroid imaging or referral to a parathyroid surgeon) should be considered.

Key learning point: Lithium can affect secretion of parathyroid hormone by causing primary hyperparathyroidism and subsequent hypercalcemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid imaging is considered in further evaluation of a patient for primary hyperparathyroidism. However, parathyroid imaging is not indicated in a patient who has features of a secondary, reversible cause of hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, which can also result in an elevated parathyroid hormone level, is an autosomal-dominant mutation in the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands and kidney that leads to an increase in the serum calcium level necessary to suppress parathyroid hormone secretion by the parathyroid. Screening for this condition consists of measuring 24-hour urinary calcium excretion. However, the patient’s past normal serum calcium levels make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum protein electrophoresis would be the next step if multiple myeloma were the suspected cause of the patient’s hypercalcemia. However, myeloma usually manifests in older patients and with other findings such as anemia, kidney dysfunction, and bone pain. Moreover, the parathyroid hormone level would be low in myeloma.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 3-year-old girl who is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. She was found with an open bottle of her mother's antidepressant medication. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her temperature is 39.9°C, pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination reveals dilated pupils, dry lips, flushed skin, and decreased bowel sounds. Electrocardiography shows sinus tachycardia and a widened QRS complex (130 ms). Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen has been started. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

TCAs block the fast sodium channels in the myocardium, which decreases cardiac conduction velocity, resulting in prolonged QRS complexes and cardiac arrhythmias. In cases of TCA overdose involving ventricular arrhythmias or QRS complexes > 100 ms, IV sodium bicarbonate is indicated to alkalinize plasma so that protein binding of TCAs (weak bases) can prevent the drug from binding to the fast sodium channels. Additionally, sodium bicarbonate increases the extracellular sodium concentration, which makes the remaining fast sodium channels more active. In patients with TCA overdose, the duration of QRS complexes correlates with the likelihood of developing ventricular arrhythmias and seizures and can, therefore, be used as an indicator of the severity of intoxication. In patients presenting within 2 hours of TCA ingestion, gastric decontamination with activated charcoal can be performed if the airway is established and circulation is secured.

Antiarrhythmics that are typically used in the management of ventricular tachycardia (e.g., procainamide, amiodarone) are contraindicated in TCA overdose because of the risk of worsening sodium channel blockade and/or QTc prolongation.

Key learning point: In tricyclic antidepressant overdose with cardiac toxicity (e.g., widened QRS), intravenous sodium bicarbonate is the antidote of choice to stabilize cardiac membranes and prevent arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine can be used as an antidote in severe anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., atropine overdose). While this patient has symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity (e.g., dry skin), additional findings suggest TCA intoxication. Physostigmine is contraindicated in patients with TCA intoxication because it is associated with an increased risk of cardiac arrest and seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucagon is an antidote for beta-blocker poisoning, which can cause altered mental status and hypotension, both of which are seen here. Characteristic ECG features of beta-blocker toxicity are bradycardia (β1 receptor blockade prevents the reflex tachycardia associated with hypotension) and a wide PR interval (due to a first-degree AV block); tachycardia and wide QRS complex would not be expected. Other features seen in this patient, e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, and flushed skin (i.e., anticholinergic effects), cannot be explained by beta-blocker poisoning. Glucagon administration is not recommended in the management of patients with TCA intoxication, as it would worsen the tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid intoxication. Although this patient has some features of opioid intoxication (respiratory depression, decreased bowel sounds, altered mental status, hypotension), she has ingested TCAs, not opioids. Additionally, the patient presents with mydriasis instead of miosis, which would be the expected finding in opioid intoxication. Hyperthermia and wide QRS complexes on ECG cannot be explained by opioid toxicity. Naloxone causes tachycardia and would worsen this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is the antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, which can manifest with nausea, vomiting, and, in the case of acute liver failure, altered mental status. In acetaminophen poisoning, hepatic toxicity typically becomes symptomatic within 24 hours of ingestion and manifests with additional symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. The anticholinergic features seen in this patient (e.g., mydriasis, hyperthermia, flushed skin, arrhythmia) cannot be explained by acetaminophen poisoning. NAC is not used in the treatment of TCA toxicity.
questions.hint: This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 2 hours after ingesting approximately 30 tablets of amitriptyline. She is alert but confused, with dry mucous membranes and dilated pupils. Her vital signs are stable except for a heart rate of 140 bpm. ECG is shown. Which ECG finding most strongly predicts life-threatening complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sinus tachycardia is a common finding in tricyclic antidepressant overdose due to anticholinergic effects. While sinus tachycardia indicates poisoning, it does not specifically predict seizures or ventricular arrhythmias and is not considered a marker of severe poisoning.

B) INCORRECT:

Terminal R waves in aVR occur as part of the typical ECG pattern in tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but an alternative finding more reliably predicts seizures and ventricular arrhythmias.

C) INCORRECT:

Axis deviation can occur in tricyclic antidepressant overdose but is not predictive of severe complications such as seizures or ventricular arrhythmias.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- QRS interval of > 100 ms is the strongest predictor of severe complications including seizures and ventricular dysrhythmias in tricyclic antidepressant overdose. This finding indicates significant sodium channel blockade and warrants immediate treatment with sodium bicarbonate to prevent life-threatening complications.

E) INCORRECT:

QTc prolongation can occur in tricyclic antidepressant overdose but is not the strongest predictor of life-threatening complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after ingesting an unknown quantity of psychiatric medication 90 minutes ago. The patient is agitated. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 115; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Physical examination shows mydriasis, flushed skin, and absent bowel sounds. ECG is shown. After initiating fluid resuscitation and securing the airway, what is the next most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of anticholinergic symptoms and QRS widening > 100 ms indicates tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose. Hypertonic sodium bicarbonate is the first-line treatment for QRS prolongation in TCA poisoning; it helps overcome sodium channel blockade and prevent ventricular arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist and is not appropriate for this patient. The clinical findings of anticholinergic poisoning with QRS widening suggest tricyclic antidepressant overdose, not benzodiazepine poisoning.

C) INCORRECT:
